bibl.title: Letter from N.P. Stewart to Howard A. Kelly, February 20, 1907

div1.p: Stewart praises Kelly's book. He suggests corrections for clarification, and notes that he would emphasize the role of the Public Health Service.

div1.head: Letter from N.P. Stewart to Howard A. Kelly, February 20, 1907

opener.dateline:
AMERICAN CONSULAR SERVICE.
Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, S.A.
February 20, 1907.

div1.p:
Please do not think that I am very presump-
tious in writing to you. I once did meet you, having
been given a letter of introduction to you, some thirteen
years ago, but I have heard of you so often in a friendly
way from Dr. Fry in Washington, that as -at my request --
he sent me the last edition of your book, “Walter Reed
and Yellow Fever” I want to suggest one or two very small
amendments in the book, when it appears in it's third and
fourth, and “Xth.” editions. For, that the book will be
called for to more editions, I cannot doubt. It is the
clearest exposition, both of the mosquito theory (please
excuse the use of the word theory, I should say causation)
od both Malarial infection, and Yellow Fever infection,
i.e. the clearest exposition, written in popular terms,
and capable of being understood by those who are not “Med-
icos” -- that I, or, probably- anyone else has ever had the
pleasure of reading. And, the tribute that you pay to
Dr. Reed, although no one could ask for any kinder terms
than those in which you have expressed yourself, or any
expressions of more lasting and reasonable appreciation
of the wonderful addition to medical knowledge which were
initiated and developed to full perfection by him, still,
Dr. ReedKelly Page 2.
still, although you write to well, and appreciativly, there
is no one who could in mere words show just what a bene-
fit he has given freely to the world. It will take ages
of time to understand this, and even then when it might be un-
derstood, it will fail to be appreciated, because all the
old works speaking of the havoc to life, health, commerce
and fellow feeling caused by epidemics of yellow fever,
will be so hard to understand, in the light of the knowledge
given to the world by Reed, that people will imagine all the
old works on this subject, and the many press articles, etc.
to be gross exaggerations, etc. etc., caused no doubt by
fear of a disease not understood, and for the non-under9
standing of whch, they, in the light inherited by them from
one who hs left us but recently, they themselves will not
be able to see any reason for.

But, I would suggest in fairness to a Government
Service, whose personnel has suffered death from this
disease in persuance of their duties in epidemic work and, in disinfecting and
cleaning ships -- although much of this disinfection is now
sown to have been unnecessary -- (but this fact was not
appreciated at the period when these deaths occurred)
that a few changes be made in your next edition of your
book.

These are really so very small that it may seem to
you hardly worth while to make them. However they are as
follows.

On page 188, 5th line from the top of page you say that
Dr. Kelly, Page 3.
“In 1903, Dr. Guiteras was appointed by the Surgeon General
to investigate” etc. etc. Now, the Surgeon General, was
Walter Wyman, of the U.S. Public Health and Marine Hospital
Service, not of the U.S. Army, as would naturally be un-
derstood by inference from the frequent mention of the
Surgeons General of the Army in service during the periods
which your review of Dr. Reed's life covers.

Again, on the next page but one, you mention “Past
Assistant Surgeon Von Ezdorf” but there is no mention of
the Service to which he belongs. The Army has no such rank
but the Navy has, and unless the Service to which the writer
of the article (Dr Guiteras) belonged is clear, there might be some con-
fusion. The article in question you show is taken from
the Journal of the American Medical Association, but I
think, that it might be clearer if the writer's Gocern-
ment position were cleary stated.

Now, Dr. Kelly, do not think that I am writing in any
spirit of cavil. I was a Commissioned Officer of the Ma-
rine Hospital Service, from 1892 to 1899, and then I went to
the Phillipines with the Army, first as an Acting Assistant
Surgeon, later as a Captain and Assistant Surgeon, of Vol-
unteers, and then again as a Contract Surgeon, and resign-
ing in 1903, came down here as the representative -- a non
commissioned officer -- of the U.S. Public Health and Marine
Hospital Service. I am in no way biased, I mean as re-
gards any love for either the Army or the M.H.S., but I
Dr. Kelly/ Page 4.
words and now, do think this. The U.S. Public Health and Marine Hospital
Service, has had more or less for (the past 15 years, always increasing however --
I am glad to say --) jurisdiction of the quarantine affairs
of the United States, and during this time, to my knowl-
edge four of their personnel have died from yellow fever,
at quarantines, and during epidemics,
and of course others have had the disease and recovered.
Although their efforts were in certain ways misdirected, at
all events unnecessary in the light of knowledge given to
the world by Dr. Reed and his brave associates, still the
work of the Service was given in quite as sincere a way,
with just as much indifference to risk of life and health
and with quite as sincere a desire to serve mankind, as
was the successful work of Dr. Reed, and his Commission.

That is a point that so mny people would naturally
lose sight of. The successful people get all the credit
(And that is correct)
for a work successfully accomplished. But, in making any
estimate of Government work of this character, one must
remember that the U.S.P.H.M.H.S. did all they could-accor-
ding to knowledge at that time -- to prevent the introduc-
tion and spread (when introduced) of yellow fever. And,
their work has in the main been good and praiseworthy.

Thousands of Southern citizens of the United States
will bear witness to that fact, to-day, and at any time
during the past twenty years.

Your conclusions on the lower half of page
240 every one, who stops to think and who knows anything
at all, will without reservation assent to, and hold up.
Dr. Kelly. Page 5.
Do not think that what is known as “Esprit de Corps”
makes me write as I do about these small matters. I have
this feeling both for the P.H.M.H.S., and for the Army, but
it is a simple feeling that where any credit could be given
to the M.H.S. or to the Army, it should be done. At the same time
I can fully appreciate such words as “even Wasdin” and one
or two others wich appear in the book. And, also I can
appreciate the remarks of the Dean of the Liverpool School
of Tropical Medicine, on page 202 and 203, where the P.H.M.
H.S. is given credit for work performed.

You certainly know that to admit oneself in
the wrong theoretically, as the PH. M.H.S. has had to do,
even although no blame can really be said to be laid to
their charge -- except perhaps slowness of conviction -- is
hard for any person or any Service to do, but the Public
Health Service did it, and have certainly helped to prove
the truth of Dr. Reed's findings in regard to yellow fe-
ver, as your own book clearly shows.

But, all this kind of talk aside, I can only most
heartily congratulate you on your book. Anyone would be
proud to think, that after their demise, some friend would
write of them as you do of Dr. Reed. I have known hun-
dreds of his friends and students, and everyone has spo-
ken of him personally as you do in your review of his life.

I only met him once myself, and then only for a few mo-
ments, and therefor I can not speak of my own impressions
of him, for I had no real ones, but, your book is as I say
Dr. Kelly. Page 6.
a lasting memorial to his character and to his work.

I can only congratulate you again on being its writer.
Hoping that you will pardon me for writing as I do, and
only wishing that the Public Health Service figured a little
more prominently as having worked faithfully and well-all
things considered -- for so many years as regards Yellow
Fever, (for if one does not know the real cause of a dis-
ease, one is after all rather fighting in the dark, and
can only for the time being, do the best that one knows
how, or can learn how)--- (and this the Service certainly
did, although there were of course thousands of needless
restrictions viewed in the light of our present knowledge)
---
